msIdentifier.repository: Pembroke College Library: on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Knighthood and Battle
Knyghthode and bataile
msItem.textLang: Middle English (opening lines of the proheme in Latin)

msItem.title: Proheme
msItem.incipit: 1r: Salue festa dies mauortis auete kalende... Hail halyday deuout Alhail kalende
msItem.explicit: 2v: What Chilvaler is best on it bewere

msItem.title: Knighthood and Battle
msItem.incipit: 3r: Sumtyme it was the gise among the wise
msItem.explicit: 55v: That neither he take of ner multiplye

msItem.note: Versified paraphrase and translation of Vegetius, De re militari.
Text also preserved in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Ashmole 45, Part 2 and London, British Library, Cotton MS Titus A.XXIII, ff. 2r-53v.

foliation.p: [1]-53 (for ff. 3-55, numbering commencing with 2 on f. 4r).

list.item: Quire 78-1 (ff. 49-55: 8th leaf excised, after f. 55, probably blank)

p.note: In Quire 5, sheet 4 was misbound as 2. Scribbles on these leaves and patterns of off-set, indicate that the misbinding predates the current 19th-century binding.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures in the usual late medieval form.

supportDesc.condition: Scribbles and scrawls in crayon on ff. 50 and 53. Spotting and staining of the leaves at the beginning and end of the manuscript (ff. 1-13 and 46-56).

layout.seg: Single columns, frame ruling in ink with dividing lines for stanzas, 28 lines in four stanzas, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in secretary script by one scribe.

decoNote.p: At the opening of the proheme, a large cadel in brown ink (f. 1r).
Five- to eleven-line initials in blue, with infill and marginal flourishing in red.

note.p: Pen-trials throughout, including, on f. 56r, parts of two documents.
Scribbles in crayon in the margins of ff. 50r-50v and 53r).

binding.p: Folio 56 perhaps formerly the rear pastedown of the medieval binding, now lifted.

origin.p: According to P.R. Robinson, 'The translation seems to have been completed in the years 1458-59. Its proem, lines 1-88 (ff. 1r-2v), celebrates the triumphant entry of Henry VI into London on 25 March 1458, and in lines 978-1026 (ff. 19r-19v) the poet refers to the political situation after the Yorkist defeat at the battle of Ludiford, in October 1459. However, there is no mention of Henry's defeat and capture in 1460 or the ensuing events that led to Edward IV's accession. In the only other two copies...the proem is omitted...and the name of Edward IV is substituted for that of Henry in lines 121 and 2880 (ff. 3v and 53r). This would suggest that the Pembroke copy was made before March 1461 when Henry was deposed, and certainly before his death in 1471.'

provenance.p: 1v: 'Thomas bynder', written upside-down in the lower margin (late 15th century) ('Thomas' repeated in similar fashion on f. 20r).
56r: copy of a warrant made out for Richarde Artur, addressed to the Keeper of the park at Wanstead, to take one buck, dated 13 Aug. 23 (most likely Hen VIII, i.e. 1531/32).
Scribbled names: 'Glyntham' (i.e. Glentham, Lincs.), 'Brantyngthorp' (i.e. Bruntingthorpe, Lincs.) and 'Lyncoln' (16th century).

acquisition.p: First noted as part of the collection of Pembroke College by H. Schenkl, Bibliotheca Patrum Latinorum Britannica, II/2 (Vienna, 1898), p. 5.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by Rodney M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Pembroke College, Cambridge (2022) (used here by kind permission of the author).

availability.p: Researchers should note that Pembroke College's western European medieval manuscripts are housed at Cambridge University Library (CUL). Scholars who wish to consult Pembroke College manuscripts should contact the Manuscripts Reading Room at CUL to arrange their visit; all CUL admissions procedures will apply. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library. For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
